articles.headline: Google Tries Something Retro: Made in the U.S.A.
articles.snippet: With its wireless Nexus Q home media player, Google is resisting the accepted wisdom that consumer electronics products can no longer be built in the United States.
articles.abstract: With its wireless Nexus Q home media player, Google is resisting the accepted wisdom that consumer electronics products can no longer be built in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Etched into the base of Google’s new wireless home media player that was introduced on Wednesday is its most intriguing feature. On the underside of the Nexus Q is a simple inscription: “Designed and Manufactured in the U.S.A.”

articles.headline: Prescription Drug to Aid Weight Loss Wins F.D.A. Backing
articles.snippet: The first prescription diet pill in 13 years to gain Food and Drug Administration approval, Belviq, gives the roughly one-third of American adults considered obese a new option.
articles.abstract: The first prescription diet pill in 13 years to gain Food and Drug Administration approval, Belviq, gives the roughly one-third of American adults considered obese a new option.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first new prescription diet pill in 13 years won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, providing a new option for the roughly one-third of American adults considered obese.

articles.headline: Madoff’s Brother Sets Plea Deal in Ponzi Case
articles.snippet: Peter Madoff, the younger brother of the convicted fraudster Bernard L. Madoff, is expected to admit to, among other things, falsifying records, making false statements to securities regulators and obstructing the work of the Internal Revenue Serv...
articles.abstract: Peter Madoff, the younger brother of the convicted fraudster Bernard L. Madoff, is expected to admit to, among other things, falsifying records, making false statements to securities regulators and obstructing the work of the Internal Revenue Service.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and DIANA B. HENRIQUES

articles.headline: Tiny Camera to Rival the Pros
articles.snippet: The tiny, very expensive Sony RX100 camera will be available in late July. Its one-inch sensor is the biggest ever placed into a pocketable zoom camera.
articles.abstract: The tiny, very expensive Sony RX100 camera will be available in late July. Its one-inch sensor is the biggest ever placed into a pocketable zoom camera.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a review of the best pocket camera ever made.

articles.headline: After Years of False Hopes, Signs of a Turn in Housing
articles.snippet: Roughly six years after the housing market began its longest and deepest slide since the Great Depression, home sales and an increase in sales prices indicate that the market is recovering.
articles.abstract: Roughly six years after the housing market began its longest and deepest slide since the Great Depression, home sales and an increase in sales prices indicate that the market is recovering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Announcements of a housing recovery have become a wrongheaded rite of summer, but after several years of false hopes, evidence is accumulating that the optimists may finally be right.

articles.headline: To Lure ‘Twilight’ Teenagers, Classic Books Get Bold Looks
articles.snippet: Publishers are dressing classic novels like “Emma” and “Jane Eyre” in sexy new covers, hoping to appeal to the young-adult readers who made “Twilight” and “The Hunger Games” so popular.
articles.abstract: Publishers are dressing classic novels like “Emma” and “Jane Eyre” in sexy new covers, hoping to appeal to the young-adult readers who made “Twilight” and “The Hunger Games” so popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: Teenagers are still reading the classics. They just don’t want them to look so, well, classic.

articles.headline: News Corp. Announces Spinoff of Newspapers
articles.snippet: The company said it plans to divide within 12 months into two entities, one that would include its lucrative entertainment assets and a smaller one featuring its newspapers.
articles.abstract: The company said it plans to divide within 12 months into two entities, one that would include its lucrative entertainment assets and a smaller one featuring its newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch was getting cold feet. For months, his top lieutenants at News Corporation had been prodding him to spin off the newspaper unit, which was underperforming but had long been close to his heart.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Everywoman Finds Her Place Is in the Presidential Palace
articles.snippet: Naglaa Ali Mahmoud has drawn both praise and criticism as the traditionalist everywoman wife of Egypt’s first Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.abstract: Naglaa Ali Mahmoud has drawn both praise and criticism as the traditionalist everywoman wife of Egypt’s first Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Naglaa Ali Mahmoud wears an Islamic head covering that drapes down to her knees, did not attend college and never took her husband’s last name, because that is a Western convention that few Egyptians follow. She also refuses the title of first lady, in favor of simply Um Ahmed, a traditional nickname that identifies her as the mother of Ahmed, her eldest son.
articles.byline: By Mayy El Sheikh and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Barclays Chief Faces Political Firestorm
articles.snippet: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the chief executive of Barclays, faced a political backlash a day after the big British bank agreed to pay more than $450 million to settle accusations it had attempted to manipulate key interest rates.
articles.abstract: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the chief executive of Barclays, faced a political backlash a day after the big British bank agreed to pay more than $450 million to settle accusations it had attempted to manipulate key interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., faced a political backlash on Thursday, a day after the British bank agreed to pay more than $450 million to settle accusations that it had attempted to manipulate key interest rates.

articles.headline: A Low-Key Transition for ‘Today’ Hosts
articles.snippet: Ann Curry gave a tearful farewell on the “Today” show Thursday, but NBC’s introduction of her replacement — said to be Savannah Guthrie — will be a quiet affair.
articles.abstract: Ann Curry gave a tearful farewell on the “Today” show Thursday, but NBC’s introduction of her replacement — said to be Savannah Guthrie — will be a quiet affair.
articles.lead_paragraph: 11:54 p.m. | Updated On Friday morning, Savannah Guthrie is scheduled to be sitting beside Matt Lauer on the “Today” show — and once again, NBC’s ability to pull off talent transitions will be put to the test.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Law, 5-4, in Victory for Obama
articles.snippet: In a striking victory for President Obama and Congressional Democrats, the chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., affirmed the central legislative pillar of Mr. Obama’s term.
articles.abstract: In a striking victory for President Obama and Congressional Democrats, the chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., affirmed the central legislative pillar of Mr. Obama’s term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld President Obama’s health care overhaul law, saying its requirement that most Americans obtain insurance or pay a penalty was authorized by Congress’s power to levy taxes. The vote was 5 to 4, with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. joining the court’s four more liberal members.
